column2: EARLY LIFE
column3: EARLY LIFE

column2: In the town hall of the seaport of St Malo there hangs a portrait of Jacques Cartier, the great sea-captain of that place, whose name is associated for all time with the proud title of 'Discoverer of Canada.' The picture is that of a bearded man in the prime of life, standing on the deck of a ship, his bent elbow resting upon the gunwale, his chin supported by his hand, while his eyes gaze outward upon the western ocean as if seeking to penetrate its mysteries.
column3: In the town hall of the seaport of saint Malo there hangs a portrait of Jacques Cartier, the great sea captain of that place, whose name is associated for all time with the proud title of 'Discoverer of Canada.' The picture is that of a bearded man in the prime of life, standing on the deck of a ship, his bent elbow resting upon the gunwale, his chin supported by his hand, while his eyes gaze outward upon the western ocean as if seeking to penetrate its mysteries.

column2: The face is firm and strong, with tight-set jaw, prominent brow, and the full, inquiring eye of the man accustomed both to think and to act.
column3: The face is firm and strong, with tight set jaw, prominent brow, and the full, inquiring eye of the man accustomed both to think and to act.

column2: The costume marks the sea-captain of four centuries ago.
column3: The costume marks the sea captain of four centuries ago.

column2: A thick cloak, gathered by a belt at the waist, enwraps the stalwart figure.
column3: A thick cloak, gathered by a belt at the waist, enwraps the stalwart figure.

column2: On his head is the tufted Breton cap familiar in the pictures of the days of the great navigators.
column3: On his head is the tufted Breton cap familiar in the pictures of the days of the great navigators.

column2: At the waist, on the left side, hangs a sword, and, on the right, close to the belt, the dirk or poniard of the period.
column3: At the waist, on the left side, hangs a sword, and, on the right, close to the belt, the dirk or poniard of the period.

column2: How like or unlike the features of Cartier this picture in the town hall may be, we have no means of telling.

column2: Painted probably in 1839, it has hung there for more than seventy years, and the record of the earlier prints or drawings from which its artist drew his inspiration no longer survives.

column2: We know, indeed, that an ancient map of the eastern coast of America, made some ten years after the first of Cartier's voyages, has pictured upon it a group of figures that represent the landing of the navigator and his followers among the Indians of Gaspe. It was the fashion of the time to attempt by such decorations to make maps vivid.

column2: There stood until the autumn of 1908, in the French-Canadian fishing village of Cap-des-Rosiers, near the mouth of the St Lawrence, a house of very ancient date.
column3: There stood until the autumn of nineteen o eight, in the French Canadian fishing village of Cap des Rosiers, near the mouth of the saint Lawrence, a house of very ancient date.

column2: Precisely how old it was no one could say, but it was said to be the oldest existing habitation of the settlement.
column3: Precisely how old it was no one could say, but it was said to be the oldest existing habitation of the settlement.

column2: Ravaged by perhaps two centuries of wind and weather, the old house afforded but little shelter against the boisterous gales and the bitter cold of the rude climate of the Gulf.
column3: Ravaged by perhaps two centuries of wind and weather, the old house afforded but little shelter against the boisterous gales and the bitter cold of the rude climate of the Gulf.

column2: Its owner decided to tear it down, and in doing so he stumbled upon a startling discovery.

column2: He found a dummy window that, generations before, had evidently been built over and concealed.
column3: He found a dummy window that, generations before, had evidently been built over and concealed.

column2: From the cavity thus disclosed he drew forth a large wooden medallion, about twenty inches across, with the portrait of a man carved in relief.
column3: From the cavity thus disclosed he drew forth a large wooden medallion, about twenty inches across, with the portrait of a man carved in relief.

column2: Here again are the tufted hat, the bearded face, and the features of the picture of St Malo.

column2: On the back of the wood, the deeply graven initials J. C. seemed to prove that the image which had lain hidden for generations behind the woodwork of the old Canadian house is indeed that of the great discoverer.

column2: Beside the initials is carved the date 1704..

column2: If it does not show us Cartier as he was,--and we have no absolute proof in the one or the other direction,--at least it shows us Cartier as he might well have been, with precisely the face and bearing which the hero-worshipper would read into the character of such a discoverer.

column2: The port of St Malo, the birthplace and the home of Cartier, is situated in the old province of Brittany, in the present department of Ille-et-Vilaine.
column3: The port of saint Malo, the birthplace and the home of Cartier, is situated in the old province of Brittany, in the present department of Ille et Vilaine.

column2: It is thus near the lower end of the English Channel. To the north, about forty miles away, lies Jersey, the nearest of the Channel Islands, while on the west surges the restless tide of the broad Atlantic.
column3: It is thus near the lower end of the English Channel. To the north, about forty miles away, lies Jersey, the nearest of the Channel Islands, while on the west surges the restless tide of the broad Atlantic.

column2: The situation of the port has made it a nursery of hardy seamen.
column3: The situation of the port has made it a nursery of hardy seamen.

column2: The town stands upon a little promontory that juts out as a peninsula into the ocean.
column3: The town stands upon a little promontory that juts out as a peninsula into the ocean.

column2: The tide pours in and out of the harbour thus formed, and rises within the harbour to a height of thirty or forty feet.
column3: The tide pours in and out of the harbour thus formed, and rises within the harbour to a height of thirty or forty feet.

column2: The rude gales of the western ocean spend themselves upon the rocky shores of this Breton coast.
column3: The rude gales of the western ocean spend themselves upon the rocky shores of this Breton coast.

column2: Here for centuries has dwelt a race of adventurous fishermen and navigators, whose daring is unsurpassed by any other seafaring people in the world.

column2: The history, or at least the legend, of the town goes back ten centuries before the time of Cartier.
column3: The history, or at least the legend, of the town goes back ten centuries before the time of Cartier.

column2: It was founded, tradition tells us, by a certain Aaron, a pilgrim who landed there with his disciples in the year 507 A.D., and sought shelter upon the sea-girt promontory which has since borne the name of Aaron's Rock.
column3: It was founded, tradition tells us, by a certain Aaron, a pilgrim who landed there with his disciples in the year five hundred seven a d, and sought shelter upon the sea girt promontory which has since borne the name of Aaron's Rock.

column2: Aaron founded a settlement.

column2: To the same place came, about twenty years later, a bishop of Castle Gwent, with a small band of followers.
column3: To the same place came, about twenty years later, a bishop of Castle Gwent, with a small band of followers.

column2: The leader of this flock was known as St Malo, and he gave his name to the seaport.

column2: But the plain truth is that we know nothing of the circumstances that preceded the marriage, and have only the record of 15199 on the civil register of St Malo: 'The nuptial benediction was received by Jacques Cartier, master-pilot of the port of Saincte-Malo, son of Jamet Cartier and of Geseline Jansart, and Marie Katherine des Granches, daughter of Messire Honore des Granches, chevalier of our lord the king, and constable of the town and city of Saint-Malo.'

column2: Out of this background, then, of uncertainty and conjecture emerges, in 1534, Jacques Cartier, a master-pilot in the prime of life, now sworn to the service of His Most Christian Majesty Francis I of France, and about to undertake on behalf of his illustrious master a voyage to the New Land.

column2: CHAPTER II
column3: CHAPTER two

column2: THE FIRST VOYAGE--NEWFOUNDLAND AND LABRADOR
column3: THE FIRST VOYAGE-NEWFOUNDLAND AND LABRADOR

column2: It was on April 20, 1534, that Jacques Cartier sailed out of the port of St Malo on his first voyage in the service of Francis I. Before leaving their anchorage the commander, the sailing-masters, and the men took an oath, administered by Charles de Mouy, vice-admiral of France, that they would behave themselves truly and faithfully in the service of the Most Christian King.
column3: It was on april twentieth fifteen thirty four, that Jacques Cartier sailed out of the port of saint Malo on his first voyage in the service of Francis the first Before leaving their anchorage the commander, the sailing masters, and the men took an oath, administered by Charles de Mouy, vice admiral of France, that they would behave themselves truly and faithfully in the service of the Most Christian King.

column2: The company were borne in two ships, each of about sixty tons burden, and numbered in all sixty-one souls.
column3: The company were borne in two ships, each of about sixty tons burden, and numbered in all sixty one souls.
